title: What albums are people listening to during the quarantine to get through it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Cows - entire discography plus singles, non album tracks and an alleged copy of their self released last-show-only CD-R with some of those are tracks and some remixes of their last album tracks. Wintergatan - everything they release through Bandcamp and YouTube Master Boot Record - same as above AC/DC - entire discography (Australian) and random live bootlegs when cleaning the house Brian Eno - Music For Installations Eliane Radigue - entire discography Rolling Stones - Sticky Fingers, Exile On Main Street (Super Deluxe Editions) Hayley Williams' EP Albert Ayler - Spiritual Unity, Ghosts, some from the Holy Ghost box set John Coltrane - the Japan Concert, Ascension, A Love Supreme (the deluxe edition with outtakes and live performance) Zappa/Mothers - Absolutely Free, We're Only In It For The Money, the Hot Rats box set, random tracks from his entire career Lots of my kid's child music, some of it sucks, some of it rules like Palavra Cantada, Mundo Aflora, Duo Badulaque, Grupo Triii, Pequeno Cidadão Yes' Tales From Topographic Oceans and live bootlegs, random tracks King Crimson's Larks Tongues In Aspic box set and random tracks from their newer and newer archival releases. I guess that's all.

I’m listening to this guy:  Popular music isn’t doing it for me. In times of stress, disruption and disorder, you need someone who stared disorder in the face and said Na ja? Verfick dich bloß! Ludwig van Beethoven lived through: losing his mother at 17 and becoming the family breadwinneran absent and hopelessly unreliable alcoholic fathergrowing deafness from his late twenties onwardsthe Napoleonic warsa profoundly unsatisfying romantic lifelosing his brother to TBa long illness which eventually killed him.He died during a thunderstorm, as if nature itself were worried that it was upstaging him. It started when I was working from home last week, enjoying the fact that I no longer had to listen to the regular office choice of BBC Radio 6—nothing against Radio 6, but the same old songs get boring after a couple of weeks’ rotation. I was in my living room, at my table, with my iPod in its dock, and it occurred to me that I’d had all of Beethoven’s symphonies on there for years but had only ever listened to Nos. 3, 5, 6, 7 and 9. So I started with No. 1. The only one left that I haven’t listened to is No. 8, and while I must admit that I’ve got them on while I’m working rather than am listening to them properly, I figure that the first listening to any long piece of music is basically something you need to get over with: its real beauties don’t become apparent till after a few listens. So now I’m looking forward to a deep dive into the composer who, of all composers, is probably the most bracing. As the late Joe Kerman wrote in the New Grove article on Beethoven: […] Beethoven’s attraction [for some musicians] rests on another aspect of the ‘symphonic ideal’, one that is less technical but probably no less essential. The combination of his musical dynamic, now extremely powerful, and extra-musical suggestions invests his pieces with an unmistakable ethical aura. Even [Donald] Tovey, the most zealous adherent of the ‘pure music’ position, was convinced that Beethoven’s music was ‘edifying’. Maybe, just maybe, this will all issue in the fulfilment of my long-held ambition to write something about the work which, last summer, displaced the Ninth as, in my estimation, the single most brilliant, epoch-making and important piece of music Beethoven ever wrote: his Symphony No. 3. It’s not like I’m not going to have some spare time on my hands. In the meantime, it’s been jazz, jazz-fusion, world music and the classics. Other quarantine favourites thus far: John McLaughlin and the One Truth Band, Electric DreamsMahavishnu Orchestra, Birds of FireArt Blakey, A Night at Birdland Vols. 1 & 2John Coltrane, Coltrane (1962)The Bothy Band, The Bothy BandVeena Sahasrabuddhe, Raga Madhmad Sarang & BhajanRonan Browne and Peter O’Loughlin, The South West Wind
